document.docAuthor: Bota-Sierra, Cornelio Andrés, Sandoval-H, Juliana & Pérez-Gutiérrez, León
document.docTitle: Telebasis noveloi Bota-Sierra & Perez-Gutierrez 2022, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Two new Telebasis Selys, 1865 species (Odonata: Zygoptera: Coenagrionidae) from Western Colombia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new Telebasis Selys, 1865 species (Odonata: Zygoptera: Coenagrionidae) from Western Colombia

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Grupo de Entomología Universidad de Antioquia (GEUA), Universidad de Antioquia, Medellín, Colombia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Examined material:
Holotype :
♂ , Colombia , Chocó Department , CEUA : Tado Municipality , Bochoromá village , N 5.29508° W 76.3910°
140 m asl
, pond in grasslands with some trees and aquatic vegetation:
24-i-2019
, Leg. C. Bota & J. Sandoval , museum code CEUA 66512
.
Allotype :
same data as holotype but museum code CEUA 66513
.
Paratypes :
same as holotype but
8-viii-2016
, Leg. C. Flórez, J.M . Sánchez, & C. Bota ;
6♂♂ ,
18-x-2018
, Leg. J. Sandoval-H, B. Cardenas , J.M. Sánchez , & C. Bota ;
3♂♂ ,
24-i-2019
, Leg. J. Sandoval-H, J.M. Sánchez , & C. Bota ;
2♂♂ ,
29-i-2019
, Leg. C. Bota. UARC :
8♂♂ , 1 ♀ , Unión Panamericana Municipality , Salero village , N 5.316944° W 76.614444°
118 m asl
,
8-x-2005
, Leg. L. A. Pérez ;
1♂ , 1♀ , Quibdó Municipality , km 10 road to Tadó , “Los Chalets” area, N 5.616515° W 76.641022°
47 m asl
.

Etymology. Named
noveloi
after Dr. Rodolfo Novelo Gutiérrez, a great friend, teacher, and devoted odonatologist, whose special interest in the immature stages led him to make great contributions to the field of odonatology. His kindness and willingness to help have motivated several students and researchers to work with odonates in Latin America.

Wings. Hyaline with dark brown venation and pt ( Figs. 7a–b ), which overlies one cell and has a ratio between distal and proximal length of about 1:1. FW with Px 12 in left and 11 in right; HW with Px 10 in.
Abdomen: Black except S1, S8–9, apical rings on S2–7, lateroventral portions of S3 and S7 light blue; lateroventral portions on S4–6 bluish gray ( Figs. 7a–c ).

Genital ligula. With four basal setae on each side, apical segment clubbed with lateral margins expanded in lateral view and directed backwards ending in a blunt tip, with a small inner fold ( Figs. 5c–d ).
Measurements. Abdomen: 28; FW: 18, HW: 17, total: 35 mm .

Head: Dorsal area of head finely sculptured making it iridescent. Black except for occipital border green, a thin line bordering compound eyes, antefrons around vertex, base of mandibles, genae, ventral portion of labrum, and ventral half of rear of head yellowish green; postclypeus and dorsal portion of labrum bluish green; ventral portion of labrum and antennae brown ( Fig. 6a ), rear of head mostly black.
Wings. Hyaline with dark brown venation and pt ( Fig. 7b ), which overlies one cell and has a ratio between distal and proximal length of about 1:1. 12 Px in FW, and10 Px in HW.
Measurements. Abdomen: 29; FW: 19, HW: 18, Total: 36 mm .

Variation in male paratypes
. number of spurs on metafemur: 6–8; on metatibia 7–10. Px 10–13 in FW, Px 9–12 in HW. Light coloration goes from light green to light blue ( Figs. 5a–b ), some specimens are mostly green. The light colored metepisternal stripe can be divided in two small stripes one close to the coxae and the other close to the alar suture ( Fig. 7a ). Amount of pruinescense on inner surface of cercus varies from totally covered to none ( Figs. 5f, h ).
Measurements: Abdomen: 28–29; FW:18–19, HW: 17–18, Total: 35–36 mm .

Variation in female paratypes .
Light coloration goes from light green and blue to brown, across some yellowish tones.
Measurements: Abdomen: 28–30; FW: 20–21, HW: 19–20, Total: 35–37 mm .

Differential diagnosis. Males of this species can be placed in group M- 4 in Garrison (2009) , because distance between bases of cerci is larger than 0.50 of the basal width of each cercus, wings are hyaline, cerci do not have a complete elongated seam and in lateral view are three times the length of paraprocts ( Figs. 5e–h ). Within this group
T. noveloi
shares the absence of red coloration on abdomen only with
T. demarara (Williamson, 1917)
; these two similar species can be differentiated because the cercus in
T. noveloi
has a ventral tooth on its inner side, directed inwards, which can be easily seen in dorsal view ( Figs. 5f–h ), which is not present in
T. demarara ,
whose cercus has instead an apical recurved tooth which is not present in
T. noveloi .
Another difference is the presence of a tubercle on hind margin of mesostigmal plate in both sexes in
T. demarara
which is lacking in
T. noveloi
. The other species in Garrison’s M4 group can also be differentiated from
T. noveloi
by: paraprocts in lateral view almost as long as cerci in
T. racenisi Bick & Bick, 1995
, whereas they are about a third of the length of cerci in
T. noveloi
; ventral side of cerci convex in lateral view in
T. rubricauda
, while in
T. noveloi
they are slightly concave; cerci with a ventrobasal process in
T. corbeti
, which is not present in
T. noveloi .
Based on the morphology of its genital ligula,
T. corbeti
belongs in group Ma-5 of Garrison (2009) , characterized by distal segment clubbed with lateral margin expanded in lateral view. Within this group the most similar species are
T. williamsoni and T. rubricauda
due to the coloration blue in thorax and black in the rear of head, and the rounded shape of the lateral margin of prothoracic posterior lobe.
Telebasis noveloi
can be differentiated from both because the lateroapical margins of the ligula are expanded in lateral view and directed backwards ending in a blunt tip.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE. 5.
Telebasis noveloi
male: head dorsal view: a, predominantly blue specimen (Tadó, Chocó); b, greenish blue specimen (Unión Panamericana, Chocó); Tadó, Chocó: genital ligula: c, ecto-lateral view; d, lateral view; caudal appendages: e, lateral view; f, dorso-lateral view; g, dorsal view; h, dorso-lateral view (covered with white pruinescence). b. t.: blunt tip; i. f.: inner fold; t.: ventral tooth.

FIGURE. 6.
Telebasis noveloi
female: a, head dorsal view (Tadó, Chocó); b, S8–10 lateral view (Unión Panamericana, Chocó); Tadó, Chocó: prothorax and anterior region of pterothorax: c, dorsal view; d, lateral view. ml. r.: medio-lateral ridge; pit.: pits behind mesepisternal plates.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Females lack mesepisternal pits lateral to mid-dorsal carina, ovipositor does not extend beyond S10 ( Fig. 6b ) and dorsum of S10 lacks a supplementary transverse carina, they lack prothoracic horns, and have thorax coloration mostly light brown with a linear mesepisternal stripe ( Figs. 6a, c–d , 7b ), which places them in Garrison’s (2009) group F5. Within this group,
T. noveloi
shares the presence of a pair of medio-lateral tubercles on the posterior lobe of prothorax ( Figs. 6c–d ) with
T. brevis Bick & Bick, 1995
,
T. corbeti ,
and
T. selaopyge De Marmels, 1989
, but it can be differentiated from all of them by the ridge-like nature of these tubercles ( Figs. 6c–d ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE. 7.
Telebasis noveloi :
a, male in lateral view (Tadó, Chocó); Unión Panamericana, Chocó: b, pair in tandem; c, male dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Habitat and Ecology. This new species has only been so far found in three localities in the Chocó lowlands ( Fig. 4 ), where it inhabits small ponds with emergent vegetation, and shares its habitat with
Dythemis nigra Martin, 1897
,
D. sterilis Hagen, 1861
,
Erythemis plebeja (Burmeister, 1839)
,
Erythrodiplax andagoya Borror, 1942
,
E. fusca (Rambur, 1842)
,
Idiataphe cubensis (Scudder, 1866)
,
Rhodopygia hinei Calvert, 1907
,
Pantala flavescens (Fabricius, 1798)
,
Perithemis mooma Kirby, 1889
,
O. cultriformis Calvert, 1907
,
O. sulphurata Hagen, 1868
,
M. ocellata Martin, 1897
,
Tramea abdominalis (Rambur, 1842)
,
T. binotata (Rambur, 1842)
,
A. trilobatum Leonard, 1977
, and
Argia translata Hagen, 1865
.
